Situation1: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story:
I stood in the convent hallway, mop in hand, staring at the muddy footprints trailing in from the storm. The wind outside howled, rattling the stained-glass windows, and I could see the dust swirling in the corners, settling on the polished floors I’d worked so hard to keep spotless. As the housekeeping cleaner, I was expected to maintain the house’s cleanliness, especially now, when the rain and wind brought in more mess than ever. My supervisor had already reminded me twice this week that standards must not slip, no matter the weather.

But my habit felt heavy on my shoulders, a reminder of my other calling. As a nun, I was expected to serve the community, and now, after the hurricane, the mayor himself had come to our door, pleading for help. Hundreds were homeless, desperate for food, shelter, and comfort. My sisters were already gathering supplies, and I could hear their voices echoing down the hall, calling for me to join them.

I felt torn, my heart pounding with anxiety. The mop trembled in my grip as I looked from the dirty floor to the open door, where the world outside waited for me to choose.
